linkTarget.anchoringText: The oil bearing sands are divided into three main reservoirs (Lower, Middle and Upper) separated by maximum flooding surfaces (MFS) (Figure 1). The main reservoir intervals are further split into multiple stratigraphic intervals (Figure 1) for mapping and well planning. Siltstones, lignites and shales bound the sands vertically and shales thicker than 10’ are considered as effective seals for hydrocarbons.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: A type well-log showing three main reservoirs Lower (L), Middle (M) and Upper (U). Additional stratigraphic tops are marked by solid lines.

formatted-caption.caption-text: A type well-log showing three main reservoirs Lower (L), Middle (M) and Upper (U). Additional stratigraphic tops are marked by solid lines.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Lower (L)
Middle (M)
Upper (U)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Lower reservoir is the deepest and the most prolific reservoir in the field and is the focus of this work. Figure 2 shows a south-west (SW) north-east (NE) cross section, with well logs from four wells in the Lower reservoir. The four well locations are superimposed on the net pay map of AMV-125, the deepest stratigraphic interval (Figure 2). The top interval of the Lower reservoir is AMV-155, which is overlain by a maximum flooding surface (MFS) that constitutes a regional seal across the field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Lower Reservoir (L) stratigraphic cross-section and AMV-125 net sand map with relative location of wells used to create the stratigraphic cross section.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Lower Reservoir (L) stratigraphic cross-section and AMV-125 net sand map with relative location of wells used to create the stratigraphic cross section.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Heavy and extra heavy oil viscosity is a strong function of temperature, unlike light oil. Figure 3 shows a typical dependence of Huyapari dead oil on temperature. The significant depth variation in this field across the large operational area causes significant change in reservoir temperature (Tankersley and Waite, 2003) and hence, significant variation in oil viscosity at in-situ conditions. Representation of accurate reservoir temperature and associated oil viscosity is critical to obtain a reliable production forecast.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: a) Variation of dead oil viscosity with temperature, b) ASTM plot for dead oil viscosity, c) in-situ live oil viscosity with reservoir depth.

formatted-caption.caption-text: a) Variation of dead oil viscosity with temperature, b) ASTM plot for dead oil viscosity, c) in-situ live oil viscosity with reservoir depth.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Variation of dead oil viscosity with temperature
ASTM plot for dead oil viscosity
in-situ live oil viscosity with reservoir depth.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The field has been developed using long laterals, drilled from multiwell drilling pads (Figure 4). Length of the horizontal laterals ranges from 4000 to 8000 ft., with an average of about 6000 ft. Some of these established world record for length of slotted liners (Acharya et al. 2004) in the past.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: (a) A schematic diagram of a well pad used for exploitation of extra-heavy oil fields in Orinoco, (b) multi well development from drilling pads in AMV-125 sand of the Lower reservoir.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) A schematic diagram of a well pad used for exploitation of extra-heavy oil fields in Orinoco, (b) multi well development from drilling pads in AMV-125 sand of the Lower reservoir.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: A schematic diagram of a well pad used for exploitation of extra-heavy oil fields in Orinoco
multi well development from drilling pads in AMV-125 sand of the Lower reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: As noted, LWD measurements were used to steer the well during drilling in order to maintain well trajectory in pay zone, but not all of the horizontal section was drilled in reservoir quality rock due to uncertainty in channel location. These wells are completed with 7” slotted liner. The LWD information in the completed section was used to calculate the effective well length (Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Well path with Gamma ray signature; green section shows the liner completion.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well path with Gamma ray signature; green section shows the liner completion.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Most of the data shows that the effective well length is higher than 60% of the drilled lateral section with an average value of about 80% of the lateral section (Figure 6). Less than 5% of the wells have effective well length less than 60% of its drilled lateral length.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Effective well length compared to drilled lateral length (from the Lower reservoir).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Effective well length compared to drilled lateral length (from the Lower reservoir).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Allocated well production data was used to calculate IP. The oil rate averaged over a 30-day period (discounting non-producing days) was considered as IP (Figure 7a). IP estimated by averaging provided a better assessment of sustained rate than allocated calendar rate values. Well test data were used to benchmark production data so as to have improved confidence in production data allocation (Figure 7b). In general, the allocation factor was very high (95-97%) for the data in this study.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: a) Allocated oil production rate and 30 days producing average rate with time b) allocated production rate and well test rate vs. time.

formatted-caption.caption-text: a) Allocated oil production rate and 30 days producing average rate with time b) allocated production rate and well test rate vs. time.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Allocated oil production rate and 30 days producing average rate with time
allocated production rate and well test rate vs. time.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Due to uncertainty in local geology, only a part of the well contacts reservoir quality sand and effectively contributes to the fluid production. Figure 6 shows that on average the effective well length is 80% of the drilled lateral length for this reservoir. Figure 8 captures the scatter of IP vs. effective well lengths (calculated per the criteria outlined in Table 2) of wells completed in AMV-125 sand of the Lower reservoir. Wells with higher effective length showed better performance (higher IP) than those with lower effective length. Similar relationships were also found for other sands in the Lower reservoir.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Initial oil production rate (IP) vs. effective well length.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Initial oil production rate (IP) vs. effective well length.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The IP shows a strong and clear trend with depth (Figures 9a and 9b), with IPs increasing with increasing reservoir depth. This is caused by lower oil viscosity (due to higher temperature) and higher pressure in deeper reservoirs. As mentioned earlier, the field has a large depth variation and a geothermal gradient causes the reservoir temperature to increase with depth. The viscosity variations with temperature and reservoir depth are shown in Figure 3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: (a) Initial oil production rate (IP) vs. average reservoir depth, (b) IP normalized to effective well length vs. average reservoir depth.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) Initial oil production rate (IP) vs. average reservoir depth, (b) IP normalized to effective well length vs. average reservoir depth.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Initial oil production rate (IP) vs. average reservoir depth
IP normalized to effective well length vs. average reservoir depth.

linkTarget.anchoringText: A study using a single horizontal well (Figure 10) with uniform reservoir properties (mid properties from Table 3) shows that coarse-scale models do not capture the pressure depletion and gas saturation change observed at the fine scale. Typical grid sizes used in the previous studies used coarse-scale dimensions of 328 ft. × 328 ft. in areal (x and y) and 10 ft. in vertical (z) directions. Figure 11 shows that the coarse grid blocks model significantly under-predict gas production rate and over-predict oil production rate and cumulative recovery.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Single well homogeneous model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Single well homogeneous model

linkTarget.anchoringText: A study using a single horizontal well (Figure 10) with uniform reservoir properties (mid properties from Table 3) shows that coarse-scale models do not capture the pressure depletion and gas saturation change observed at the fine scale. Typical grid sizes used in the previous studies used coarse-scale dimensions of 328 ft. × 328 ft. in areal (x and y) and 10 ft. in vertical (z) directions. Figure 11 shows that the coarse grid blocks model significantly under-predict gas production rate and over-predict oil production rate and cumulative recovery.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of calculated profiles from fine and coarse model: oil rate and cumulative, gas rate and cumulative and GOR.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of calculated profiles from fine and coarse model: oil rate and cumulative, gas rate and cumulative and GOR.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Using a uniform property model at an effective well spacing of 300 meter and ranges of reservoir properties, we identified reservoir properties which have largest impact on the well performance. Tornado diagrams (Figure 12) generated at different times (5 and 35 years) of depletion helped to quantify the impact of different reservoir properties on production behavior. Results at 5 years capture early production behavior, whereas those at 35 years represent ultimate recovery.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Impact of reservoir parameters affecting intermediate time (5 years) and late time (35 years) production behavior.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Impact of reservoir parameters affecting intermediate time (5 years) and late time (35 years) production behavior.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Oil Recovery after 5 Years
Oil Recovery after 35 Years

linkTarget.anchoringText: We consider two adjacent pads with 19 wells (Figure 13a and b) to illustrate the impact of heterogeneity on well performance. Wells in the same and adjacent pads are included, as key fluid properties such as oil-viscosity, GOR and bubble-point are similar. Also, because all wells were placed on production at nearly the same time, the initial reservoir pressures are also similar (except a small variation caused by reservoir depth).

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: a) Heterogeneous model b) well layout in the model with the green section showing the section completed by slotted liner.

formatted-caption.caption-text: a) Heterogeneous model b) well layout in the model with the green section showing the section completed by slotted liner.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Heterogeneous model
well layout in the model with the green section showing the section completed by slotted liner

linkTarget.anchoringText: The dynamic reservoir simulation model shows that local heterogeneity results in a wide range of fluid production rates for these wells. The forecasted range of performances from the simulation model (Figure 14a) was comparable to that observed in the field (see Figure 9). However, the individual well forecasts (using base model without any calibration) did not generally match the actual performances. On the other hand, forecast on a group of wells (Figure 14b) or at a pad level compares very well with field data. In other words, pad-level or a group of well-level forecasts are more reliable than well by well forecast because of local heterogeneity, which may not be precisely captured in the geologic model.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: a) Wide range of well performance (indicated by significant variation in cumulative oil production) from different wells at similar depths was captured by simulation model. Forecasts did not exactly match the actual performance at the well level. Field data are shown by green markers whereas the model forecasts are shown by black solid lines. (b) Forecast on a group of wells/pad level (shown by black solid lines) completed in a particular flow unit at a given average depth compares well with the field data (shown by green marker).

formatted-caption.caption-text: a) Wide range of well performance (indicated by significant variation in cumulative oil production) from different wells at similar depths was captured by simulation model. Forecasts did not exactly match the actual performance at the well level. Field data are shown by green markers whereas the model forecasts are shown by black solid lines. (b) Forecast on a group of wells/pad level (shown by black solid lines) completed in a particular flow unit at a given average depth compares well with the field data (shown by green marker).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Wide range of well performance (indicated by significant variation in cumulative oil production) from different wells at similar depths was captured by simulation model. Forecasts did not exactly match the actual performance at the well level. Field data are shown by green markers whereas the model forecasts are shown by black solid lines.
Forecast on a group of wells/pad level (shown by black solid lines) completed in a particular flow unit at a given average depth compares well with the field data (shown by green marker).

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the area under consideration, the geostatistical model honored well log data (Figure 15) of high shale volume (VShale) at the target stratigraphic interval top, but areas away from wells showed low VShale and high permeability regions (Figure 16). Connectivity through these patchy areas resulted in pressure communication between the vertically stacked flow units during production; as a result, forecasted cumulative oil production for the target sand were affected by ~10%. Model calibration to production data helped to incorporate a regional barrier between the vertically stacked intervals, making them separate flow units with no vertical communication.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Strat and production wells show presence of shale barriers (high gamma ray peaks, first log track from left among the four log tracks) at the top of the target stratigraphic interval AMV-125. The well logs are along two sections, highlighted by blue solid lines in the plan view. B6-C01 well log-tracks are shown to illustrate the type log in the Lower reservoir.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Strat and production wells show presence of shale barriers (high gamma ray peaks, first log track from left among the four log tracks) at the top of the target stratigraphic interval AMV-125. The well logs are along two sections, highlighted by blue solid lines in the plan view. B6-C01 well log-tracks are shown to illustrate the type log in the Lower reservoir.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the area under consideration, the geostatistical model honored well log data (Figure 15) of high shale volume (VShale) at the target stratigraphic interval top, but areas away from wells showed low VShale and high permeability regions (Figure 16). Connectivity through these patchy areas resulted in pressure communication between the vertically stacked flow units during production; as a result, forecasted cumulative oil production for the target sand were affected by ~10%. Model calibration to production data helped to incorporate a regional barrier between the vertically stacked intervals, making them separate flow units with no vertical communication.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Two layers of the base geological model, corresponding to the target stratigraphic interval top AMV-125, show higher volume of shale (VShale) values at the well location; areas away from wells show lower VShale value and have enough vertical permeability to establish pressure communication between vertically stacked layers.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Two layers of the base geological model, corresponding to the target stratigraphic interval top AMV-125, show higher volume of shale (VShale) values at the well location; areas away from wells show lower VShale value and have enough vertical permeability to establish pressure communication between vertically stacked layers.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Although, frictional pressure drop is an important consideration in the horizontal well design, heterogeneity largely dictates inflow along lateral. The oil inflow profiles are generally non-uniform (Jha et al., 2009) and oil rates calculated in the flow simulation models were higher in the areas of higher permeability (Figure 17). Some portions of the well did not contribute because of locally poor quality reservoir. These non-contributing zones can occur anywhere along the well. In this well, the percentage of non-contributing zone (~20% for this well) calculated from the model is comparable with the average non-effective well length (as % of drilled length), calculated using the cut-offs presented in Table 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Well inflow profile (calculated in the model) along the lateral is significantly impacted by sand quality and permeability heterogeneity along the lateral.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well inflow profile (calculated in the model) along the lateral is significantly impacted by sand quality and permeability heterogeneity along the lateral.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 18 (stock chart) shows that the smaller well spacing results in accelerated oil production and generally a small incremental recovery. Further, the effect of smaller spacing on acceleration is more pronounced in thicker and shallower reservoirs. In thicker reservoirs (having the same well spacing), OOIP is higher and therefore, incremental production in real volumes shall be proportionately higher even for similar incremental in percentage recovery. Figure 19 describes the correspondence between a tornado plot (Fig. 12) and a stock chart (Fig. 18).

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Impact of reservoir parameters combined with well spacing; three spacings of 500 meter, 300 meter and 150 meter were studied. The chart (adapted from stock chart, MS Excel™ 2010) illustrates the combined impact of well spacings and reservoir parameters in a single plot.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Impact of reservoir parameters combined with well spacing; three spacings of 500 meter, 300 meter and 150 meter were studied. The chart (adapted from stock chart, MS Excel™ 2010) illustrates the combined impact of well spacings and reservoir parameters in a single plot.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Oil Recovery after 5 years (%)
Oil Recovery after 35 years (%)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 18 (stock chart) shows that the smaller well spacing results in accelerated oil production and generally a small incremental recovery. Further, the effect of smaller spacing on acceleration is more pronounced in thicker and shallower reservoirs. In thicker reservoirs (having the same well spacing), OOIP is higher and therefore, incremental production in real volumes shall be proportionately higher even for similar incremental in percentage recovery. Figure 19 describes the correspondence between a tornado plot (Fig. 12) and a stock chart (Fig. 18).

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Correspondence between tornado plot and stock chart for reservoir thickness. The vertical red markers in the adapted stock chart results for “Base_Case,” “Thickness_Low” and” Thickness_High” parameters correspond to the three points on the tornado diagram for “Thickness” parameter (both at a given well spacing of 300 meter). The end-points on the stock chart show the effect of variation of well spacing on recovery. For a given value of reservoir parameter, the black bar with red marker shows the recovery for different well spacing: the middle marker for 300 meter, the left end of each bar for 500 meter whereas the right end of the bar for 150 meter well spacing.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Correspondence between tornado plot and stock chart for reservoir thickness. The vertical red markers in the adapted stock chart results for “Base_Case,” “Thickness_Low” and” Thickness_High” parameters correspond to the three points on the tornado diagram for “Thickness” parameter (both at a given well spacing of 300 meter). The end-points on the stock chart show the effect of variation of well spacing on recovery. For a given value of reservoir parameter, the black bar with red marker shows the recovery for different well spacing: the middle marker for 300 meter, the left end of each bar for 500 meter whereas the right end of the bar for 150 meter well spacing.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 20a and b show reservoir pressure at a midway point between two horizontal producers (for 16 sets of horizontal well pairs) at different times for the heterogeneous model (shown in Figure 13a). Figure 20 clearly shows that with time, significant reservoir pressure reduction occurs at the midway point. Further, it shows that at any given time, there is a large variation in pressure depletion. This is caused by varying degree of interwell reservoir connectivity in different parts of the reservoir because of local heterogeneity. Figure 20 shows that, on average, midway pressures reduce by about 50% in ~ 8 years from the start of production.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: a) Reservoir pressure of grid blocks midway between producers (16 set of producer pairs) vs. time b) average pressure and standard deviation of the pressures vs. time.

formatted-caption.caption-text: a) Reservoir pressure of grid blocks midway between producers (16 set of producer pairs) vs. time b) average pressure and standard deviation of the pressures vs. time.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Reservoir pressure of grid blocks midway between producers (16 set of producer pairs) vs. time
average pressure and standard deviation of the pressures vs. time.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 21 shows the field data for infill wells drilled after eight years of production. These infills were drilled midway between the existing wells. The initial oil production rates (IPs) of two infill wells are much smaller than the IP of existing wells. The field data essentially corroborates the observations made from numerical study that the late time infills’ performance will be much worse than the existing wells IP due to lower reservoir pressure and higher oil viscosity compared to the initial condition. In fact, the current performance existing wells may be used as an analog for intermediate to late time infill well IP estimate.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: Infill and existing wells oil production rate against time for two locations. The existing wells performances have been shown by black line (solid and dashed), and the infill well by green line. Time has been normalized, with zero time starting at the first date of production for the existing wells.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Infill and existing wells oil production rate against time for two locations. The existing wells performances have been shown by black line (solid and dashed), and the infill well by green line. Time has been normalized, with zero time starting at the first date of production for the existing wells.
